Classification of minerals \u2013 Silica.description: List of IMA recognized minerals and groupings

edenite.name: Edenite
edenite.caption: Edenite crystal from Bancroft District, Ontario
edenite.color: White to gray, pale to dark green, also brown and pale pinkish-brown
edenite.habit: Prismatic crystals, fibrous, as reaction rims on pyroxenes
edenite.described by source (p1343): Grundriss der Mineralogie mit Einschluss der Geognosie und Petrefactenkunde (Q57913100)

gedrite.name: Gedrite
gedrite.caption: Gedrite on a [[feldspar]] [[matrix (geology)|matrix]]
gedrite.habit: Bladed and prismatic crystals; fibrous and sheath like aggregates.
gedrite.diaphaneity: Translucent, will transmit light on thin edges.
gedrite.described by source (p1343): Description de la gédrite, nouvelle espèce minérale (Q16787431)

glaucophane.name: Glaucophane
glaucophane.caption: Bleu Gemm glaucophane with fuchsite
glaucophane.habit: slender long prisms, Massive granular to columnar

iron(II) sulfate.name: Iron(II) sulfate
iron(II) sulfate.imagecaption1: Iron(II) sulfate when dissolved in water
iron(II) sulfate.othernames: Iron(II) sulphate; Ferrous sulfate, Green vitriol, Iron vitriol, Copperas, Melanterite, Szomolnokite

oxide class of minerals.followed by (p156): carbonate and nitrate class of minerals (Q1073138)
oxide class of minerals.image (p18): Oxide mineral exhibit, Museum of Geology, South Dakota.jpg

holmquistite.name: Holmquistite
holmquistite.caption: Holmquistite from the Foote Mineral Co., [[Kings Mountain, North Carolina]]

ferrokentbrooksite.name: Ferrokentbrooksite
ferrokentbrooksite.caption: Ferrokentbrooksite, Amphibole Supergroup-166795
ferrokentbrooksite.impurities: REE (mainly Ce and Y), K, Sr

phosphate class of minerals.description: Nickel–Strunz 9 ed mineral class number 8 (isolated tetrahedral units, mainly)
phosphate class of minerals.followed by (p156): silicate class of minerals, class number 9 (Q178977)

native element class of minerals.description: Elements that occur in nature as minerals in uncombined form

ferronigerite-2N1S.name: Ferronigerite-2N1S
ferronigerite-2N1S.caption: Ferronigerite-2N1S from Stiepelmann mine, [[Arandis, Namibia|Arandis]], Swakopmund district, [[Erongo region]], Namibia
ferronigerite-2N1S.described by source (p1343): The occurrence of nigerite, a new tin mineral in quartz-sillimanite-rocks from Nigeria (Q63919319)

list of minerals.description: List of minerals for which there are articles on Wikipedia

mica.name: Mica
mica.color: purple, rosy, silver, gray ([[lepidolite]]); dark green, brown, black ([[biotite]]); yellowish-brown, green-white ([[phlogopite]]); colorless, transparent ([[muscovite]])

ferroselite.name: Ferroselite/ Dzharkenite
ferroselite.caption: Ferroselite found in Argentina
ferroselite.color: Steel-gray to tin-white with a rose tint, brass yellow

enstatite.name: Enstatite
enstatite.color: White, grey, green, yellow or brown - colorless in thin section.
enstatite.habit: Prismatic crystals, commonly lamellar, fibrous, or massive
enstatite.description: Pyroxene: magnesium-iron silicate with MgSiO3 and FeSiO3 end-members

magnesiotaaffeite-2N'2S.name: Taaffeite
magnesiotaaffeite-2N'2S.caption: Magnesiotaaffeite-2N’2S (Mg<sub>3</sub>Al<sub>8</sub>BeO<sub>16</sub>)
magnesiotaaffeite-2N'2S.class:
Dihexagonal pyramidal (6mm)
Trigonal dipyramidal ( {{overline|3}} m)
(magnesiotaaffeite-6N'3S and ferrotaaffeite-6N'3S)
magnesiotaaffeite-2N'2S.color: Colorless, greyish violet, violet red, red, greenish, light green, pink violet, mauve
magnesiotaaffeite-2N'2S.described by source (p1343): Taaffeite, a new beryllium mineral, found as a cut gemstone (Q58148806)

topic's main category (p910): Category:Carbonate and nitrate class of minerals (Q9503904)

halide class of minerals.image (p18): Halide mineral exhibit, Museum of Geology, South Dakota.jpg

award received (p166): Order of the Red Banner of Labour (Q478850)
Alexander Fersman.educated at (p69): Faculty of Physics and Mathematics of Moscow Imperial University (Q4483556)
member of (p463): Academy of Sciences of the USSR (Q2370801)

tourmalines.name: Tourmaline
tourmalines.alt: A stone cut open and polished, revealing a bright rainbow of colors
tourmalines.color: Most commonly black, but can range from colorless to brown, red, orange, yellow, green, blue, violet, pink, or hues in between; can be bi-colored, or even tri-colored; rarely can be neon green or electric blue
tourmalines.habit: Parallel and elongated. Acicular prisms, sometimes radiating. Massive. Scattered grains (in granite).
tourmalines.birefringence: -0.018 to −0.040; typically about .020 but in dark stones it may reach .040
tourmalines.pleochroism:
{{plainlist|
*Typically moderate to strong|ref| name="GRG" |
*Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue}} *Red: definite; dark red, light red
*Green: strong; dark green, yellow-green
*Brown: definite; dark brown, light brown
*Blue: strong; dark blue, light blue
tourmalines.fluorescence: pink stones—inert to very weak red to violet in long and short wave
tourmalines.absorption: Strong narrow band at 498 nm, and almost complete absorption of red down to 640 nm in blue and green stones; red and pink stones show lines at 458 and 451 nm as well as a broad band in the green spectrum
described by source (p1343): Explanatory Dictionary of the Living Great Russian Language (Q1970746)
Small Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary (Q19180675)

fettelite.name: Fettelite
fettelite.caption: Cluster of tiny fettelite crystals in a vug from Copiapó, Atacama Region, Chile
fettelite.twinning: intimately twinned with six twin domains
fettelite.opticalprop: Biaxial,  anisotrophism weak with strong red internal reflections
fettelite.image (p18): Fettelite - Chanarcillo, Copiapo Province, Atacama Region, Chile.jpg

fingerite.name: Fingerite
fingerite.color: Black; medium gray in reflected light
fingerite.habit: Subhedral or anhedral; equant or platelike; up to 150 μm

arsenite.description: Chemical compounds containing arsenic at oxidation state +3

sulfosalt subclass of minerals.description: Complex sulfide minerals of a metal and a semi-metal, broad sense; after Moëlo, Y et al. (2008)

Classification of organic minerals.description: List of IMA recognized minerals and groupings

fletcherite.name: Fletcherite
fletcherite.color: Steel gray, creamy white in polished section
fletcherite.habit: Minute subhedral to euhedral crystals typically enclosed within other sulfide minerals

kainite.name: Kainite
kainite.image: Kainite - Grube Brefeld, Tarthun, Staßfurt, Sachsen-Anhalt.jpg
kainite.color: Colorless; yellow, brownish, greyish-green, red, violet, blue
kainite.pleochroism: Visible: X = violet, Y = blue, Z = yellowish
kainite.image (p18): Kainite - Grube Brefeld, Tarthun, Staßfurt, Sachsen-Anhalt.jpg
described by source (p1343): Ueber ein neues salz von Leopoldshall bei Stassfurth (Q63814181)

fluckite.name: Fluckite
fluckite.caption: Fluckite from the Gabe-Gottes Mine
fluckite.habit: Crystals prismatic, typically radiating to spherulitic

fluellite.name: Fluellite
fluellite.caption: Fluellite from Leveäniemi Mine, Svappavaara, Kiruna district, Lappland, Sweden
fluellite.habit: Dipyramidal crystals commonly in aggregates; powdery, massive

fluoborite.name: Fluoborite
fluoborite.caption: Fluoborite found in Italy
fluoborite.described by source (p1343): Norbergite and fluoborite, two new minerals from the Norberg mining district (Q108314699)

fluorapatite.name: Fluorapatite
fluorapatite.color: Sea-green, violet, purple, blue, pink, yellow, brown, white, colorless, may be zoned

fluorapophyllite-(K).name: Fluorapophyllite
fluorapophyllite-(K).color: Colorless, white, pink, pale, yellow, green; in thin section, colorless
fluorapophyllite-(K).habit: Tabular to prismatic crystals; may be pseudocubic

apophyllites.name: Apophyllite
apophyllites.color: Usually white, colorless; also blue, green, brown, yellow, pink, violet

list of minerals (complete).description: List of minerals recognized by the IMA

fluor-buergerite.name: Fluor-buergerite
fluor-buergerite.color: Bronze, Dark Brown, Black, Dark Purple

niobium.description: Chemical element, symbol Nb and atomic number 41
described by source (p1343): Small Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary (Q19180675)

elbaite.name: Elbaite
elbaite.image: Elbaite with albite - São José da Safira, Minas Gerais, Brazil.jpg
elbaite.color: Green, red to pink, blue, orange, yellow, colorless, multicolored
elbaite.image (p18): Elbaite with albite - São José da Safira, Minas Gerais, Brazil.jpg
elbaite.described by source (p1343): Über die chemische Formel der Turmaline (Q108917685)

fluorellestadite.name: '''Fluorellestadite'''
fluorellestadite.caption: Fluorellestadite on blue calcite from the Crestmore Quarries, California, US
fluorellestadite.color: Light red, yellow, bluish green or colorless
fluorellestadite.habit: Acicular or hexagonal prismatic crystals, and fine-grained aggregates
fluorellestadite.streak: White with a weak bluish tint
fluorellestadite.solubility: Easily soluble in dilute hydrochloric and nitric acids

fluorite.name: Fluorite
fluorite.caption: Deep green isolated fluorite crystal resembling a [[truncated octahedron]], set upon a micaceous matrix, from Erongo Mountain, Erongo Region, [[Namibia]] (overall size: 50 mm × 27 mm, crystal size: 19 mm wide, 30 g)
fluorite.color: Colorless, although samples are often deeply colored owing to impurities; Purple, lilac, golden-yellow, green, blue, pink, champagne, brown.
fluorite.habit: Well-formed coarse sized crystals; also nodular, botryoidal, rarely columnar or fibrous; granular, massive
fluorite.gravity: 3.175–3.184; to 3.56 if high in rare-earth elements
fluorite.solubility: slightly water soluble and in hot [[hydrochloric acid]]
fluorite.description: The mineral form of calcium fluoride
described by source (p1343): Small Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary (Q19180675)

fluor-liddicoatite.name: '''Fluor-liddicoatite'''
fluor-liddicoatite.caption: Liddicoatite from the Ambesabora [[pegmatite]], Madagascar.  Photo Rob Lavinsky
fluor-liddicoatite.color: Usually smoky brown, but also pink, red, green, blue, or rarely white.
fluor-liddicoatite.habit: Stout prismatic, with a curved convex trigonal outline
fluor-liddicoatite.pleochroism: Strong: O dark brown or pink, E light brown or pale pink

fluoro-richterite.name: Fluororichterite
fluoro-richterite.caption: Fluororichterite with calcite from Wilberforce, Monmouth Township, Haliburton County, Ontario, Canada (size: 6.6 x 4.4 x 3.8 cm)
fluoro-richterite.color: Brown to brownish-red, rose-red, yellow, grey-brown, also pale to dark green

fluor-uvite.name: Fluor-uvite
fluor-uvite.caption: Uvite on quartz
fluor-uvite.color: Black, greenish-black, brownish-black, brown, green, colorless
fluor-uvite.described by source (p1343): Die Mischungsreihen in der Turmalingruppe und die genetischen Bezichungen Zwischen Turmalinen und Glimmern (Q34807359)

Zincoberaunite.name: Zincoberaunite
Zincoberaunite.type locality (geology) (p2695): Cornelia shaft, Hagendorf South open cut (Q23892495)
